Circuits Help Page

In order to continue and start practicing your skills, it is really important to know what parts you are going to be given and what they do.

Parts

3V Coin Cell Battery

A 3-volt battery known as a coin cell and CR2032. This code means that the battery is 20mm in diameter and 3.2mm thick. The side with the writing is the positive (+) side, the smaller surface underneath side is the negative (-) side.

Battery Holder

A sewable plastic case that holds a 3-volt coin cell battery. The end with the E plastic form on top is the positive end.

Alligator Clips

Used to make temporary electrical connections, consisting of a clip on each end with long, narrow jaws that resemble those of an alligator.

Connector

This part is the connecting material inbetween the alligator clips. You can place down horizontal and vertical connectors to connect two alligator clips.

LED (Light Emitting Diode)

Contains a material that glows when electrical current flows through it. LEDs are polarized, meaning they have a (+) side and a (-) side and will only light up when current flows from the (+) to (-) side. LEDs produce more light with less energy than most other types of lights.

Magnetic Snaps

These sewable nickel-coated snaps are good at conducting electricity, and can serve the same purpose as a switch. Plus they are magnetic so they snap together easily!

LillyPad LED

These specialized LEDs are mounted on easily sewable modules. LilyPad LEDs are designed with a built‐in resistor and can come in many colors, including blue, pink, red, white, yellow, and green.

LillyPad Slide Switch

This sewable switch functions as an ON/OFF power switch for your circuit.

Lilly Tiny

A tiny sewable computer that is programmed to control LEDs. It can make LEDs twinkle, fade, blink, and even has a heartbeat pattern. Each pin (0-4) has a different behavior.

LillyPad Battery Holder with Switch

This 3-volt coin cell battery holder has a small slide switch installed on the board, to switch your project on or off and save battery energy. This simple board gives you 4 connection points (two positive and two negative) for sewing into your project.

Questions?

What is a Circuit?
An electric circuit is a closed loop that includes a power supply and other electrical elements like LEDs and switches. We will be using a series and a parallel loop like form circuits on our designs, however e-textiles uses predominately a parallel circuit form, which allows for more LEDs to light with less energy, thus requiring smaller sized batteries. The loop structure enables the flow of electric current from (+) to (-).

What does the e-Circuit Drawing Application do?
The e-Circuit Drawing Application is a tool that will help circuitry novices, intermediate and advanced users develop simple to complex circuit diagrams. Each circuit activity will help build upon the previous design and basic circuitry concepts. By supplying the users the parts, the user can then focus on polarity, circuit connections, and flow thus assisting in how to visually design circuits before starting to stitch the parts into a soft textile fabric with conductive thread.

What are e-Textiles?
Also known as soft circuits, e-textiles use conductive threads, fabrics, and other soft, flexible materials that are sewn into place. Using a combination of these conductive fabrics, and sewable circuitry, materials like sewable LEDs and sewable switches, you can create wearables like the e-Cuff with LEDs sewn into it. Recently, thanks to the emergence of e-textile kits like the LilyPad Arduino toolkit, anyone can make e-Textiles now.

Projects

Simple Circuit
The simple circuit is the most basic circuit you can build. At the most basic, a circuit is a continuous loop that electricty flows through. All simple circuits need a power source and an output device, such as an LED. The electricity flows from the positive end of the power source, through the output device, and back to the negative end of the power source. The tools used in this activity are:
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 1 LEDs, 4 alligator clips
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 1 LEDs, 6 alligator clips, and a switch.

e-Cuff
This is the first e-Textile project, building an e-Cuff, and teaching parallel circuitry. Projects can include any of the following:
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 2 LEDs, one magnetic snap switch and 5 alligator clips
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 3 LEDs, one magnetic snap switch and 7 alligator clips
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 4 LEDs, one magnetic snap switch and 9 alligator clips
This is the intermediate level which is not so complicated but not so easy as well. You will have to know the basics of circuitry in order to complete or go through this level.

T-Shirt
This is the second e-Textile project, teaching the use of the LillyPad Tiny. Projects can include any of the following:
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 2 LEDs, switch and 5 alligator clips
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 3 LEDs, switch and 7 alligator clips
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 4 LEDs, switch and 9 alligator clips
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 5 LEDs, switch and 11 alligator clips
  • One battery holder & 3V battery, 6 LEDs, switch and 13 alligator clips
The designs made with the LillyPad parts will help when making t-shirts fitted with the LillyPad.
